<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 390, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 AS Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 559]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 602]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 60.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 73, 126, 88]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 102, 688, 530]]<|/det|>
acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00 \times 10^{8} \text{m s}^{- 1}\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60 \times 10^{- 19} \text{C}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1 \text{u} = 1.66 \times 10^{- 27} \text{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67 \times 10^{- 27} \text{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11 \times 10^{- 31} \text{kg}\) Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02 \times 10^{23} \text{mol}^{- 1}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31 \text{J K}^{- 1} \text{mol}^{- 1}\) Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38 \times 10^{- 23} \text{J K}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67 \times 10^{- 11} \text{N m}^{2} \text{kg}^{- 2}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85 \times 10^{- 12} \text{F m}^{- 1}\) \(\left(\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}}\right) = 8.99 \times 10^{9} \text{m F}^{- 1})\) Planck constant \(h = 6.63 \times 10^{- 34} \text{J s}\) Stefan- Boltzmann constant \(\sigma = 5.67 \times 10^{- 8} \text{W m}^{- 2} \text{K}^{- 4}\)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 565, 168, 581]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 897, 89]]<|/det|>
A ball on horizontal ground is kicked towards a vertical wall. Fig. 2.1 shows the path of the ball.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 97, 796, 275]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 291, 591, 310]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 322, 920, 371]]<|/det|>
The ball has an initial velocity \(u\) at an angle of \(38^{\circ}\) to the ground. The ball travels a horizontal distance of \(9.0 \text{m}\) before striking the wall at a height \(h\) above the ground. The horizontal component \(u_{\mathrm{H}}\) of the initial velocity of the ball is \(9.5 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 384, 341, 402]]<|/det|>
Air resistance is negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 415, 144, 433]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 415, 180, 433]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 540, 181, 559]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 881, 920, 900]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 195, 920, 227]]<|/det|>
Fig. 3.1 shows an airship in flight. The airship is propelled by identical fans that can be angled to control the motion of the airship.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 920, 152]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 243, 182]]<|/det|>

<label>(i)</label>

Fig. 4.1 shows the variation with extension \(x\) of the tensile force \(F\) for two wires, G and H, made from the same material.

For the lines in Fig. 4.1:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 510, 181, 529]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Two point sources, A and B, produce coherent electromagnetic waves. The waves from A and B are emitted in phase and have wavelength \(\lambda\), as shown in Fig. 5.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 112, 838, 349]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 363, 591, 382]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 394, 821, 413]]<|/det|>

The waves in air have a wavelength of \(2.9 \times 10^{- 5} \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 549, 920, 583]]<|/det|>
An interference pattern is detected along a line parallel to AB and at a perpendicular distance of \(140 \text{m}\) from AB. The spacing between adjacent interference maxima is \(1.2 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A train travels at constant speed along a straight horizontal track towards an observer standing adjacent to the track, as shown in Fig. 6.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 114, 868, 191]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 207, 532, 225]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 6.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 237, 920, 286]]<|/det|>
The train sounds its horn continuously as it approaches the observer. The horn emits a sound of constant frequency \(251\mathrm{Hz}\). The frequency of sound heard by the observer is \(291\mathrm{Hz}\). The speed of sound in air is \(340\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 300, 146, 318]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 300, 421, 318]]<|/det|>
Calculate the speed of the train.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[512, 453, 920, 472]]<|/det|>
<form>speed = .................................................... $\text{ms}^{-1}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 453, 920, 472]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
The train approaches and then passes the observer. The intensity \(I\) of the sound heard by the observer varies with the distance \(d\) of the horn from the observer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 117, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
When the horn is at a distance \(\mathsf{x}_0\) from the observer, the intensity \(I\) of the sound heard is \(I_0\) and the amplitude \(A\) of the sound wave at the observer is \(A_0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 165, 885, 184]]<|/det|>
Fig. 6.2 shows the variation with \(d / x_0\) of \(I / I_0\) as the train moves away from the observer.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 193, 910, 587]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 602, 316, 620]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 6.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[670, 602, 740, 620]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 6.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 632, 183, 651]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 632, 868, 651]]<|/det|>
State the relationship between amplitude \(A\) and intensity \(I\) for a progressive wave.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 664, 920, 682]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 694, 181, 714]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 299, 89]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 193, 143, 211]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 193, 920, 243]]<|/det|>
A battery of electromotive force (e.m.f.) \(6.2 \text{V}\) and negligible internal resistance is connected in a circuit to a uniform resistance wire, a voltmeter, a fixed resistor and a switch, as shown in Fig. 7.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[228, 252, 767, 518]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 533, 532, 551]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 7.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 564, 920, 597]]<|/det|>
The resistance wire has resistance \(18\Omega\), length \(0.94 \text{m}\) and cross-sectional area \(7.2 \times 10^{-8} \text{m}^2\). The slider S is positioned half-way along the length of the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 612, 183, 630]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 612, 710, 630]]<|/det|>
Calculate the resistivity \(\rho\) of the material of the resistance wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 752, 920, 770]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\rho =\) .................................................... \(\Omega \text{m}\)  [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 784, 181, 802]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 784, 356, 801]]<|/det|>
The switch is open.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 798, 480, 816]]<|/det|>
State the reading on the voltmeter.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 860, 920, 878]]<|/det|>
<form>voltmeter reading = .................................................... V [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 180, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 408, 88]]<|/det|>
The switch is now closed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 102, 705, 120]]<|/det|>
State whether there is an increase, decrease or no change to:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 134, 437, 152]]<|/det|>
● the current in the battery

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 196, 416, 213]]<|/det|>
● the voltmeter reading.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 241, 920, 259]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 273, 180, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 273, 920, 305]]<|/det|>
The switch remains closed. The slider S is moved along the resistance wire so that the voltmeter reading is 3.1V.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 319, 920, 352]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 7.1, draw a cross \((\times)\) on the resistance wire to show a possible new position of the slider. [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 365, 146, 383]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 365, 794, 382]]<|/det|>
The circuit in **(b)** is altered by changing the battery for one of a different e.m.f.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 381, 319, 399]]<|/det|>
The switch is open.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 412, 645, 429]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 457, 727, 475]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 473, 720, 491]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 78, 920, 114]]<|/det|>
The nuclide \(^{23}_{12}\mathrm{Mg}\) is an isotope of magnesium that undergoes \(\beta^{+}\) decay to form a new nuclide X according to the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[303, 128, 695, 170]]<|/det|>
\[^{23}_{12}\mathrm{Mg}\rightarrow \xrightarrow{\quad \dots \dots \dots \quad }\mathrm{X} + \xrightarrow{\quad \dots \dots \dots \quad }\beta^{+} + \xrightarrow{\quad 0}_{0}\mathrm{v}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 187, 529, 207]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 217, 181, 237]]<|/det|>
